text: Maisie and Davin are finding the least common multiple (LCM) and greatest common factor (GCF) for the numbers 42 and 36.

Maisie's Method

I make a list of all the common factors and common multiples for the two numbers. I use them to find the LCM and GCF.

Devin's Method

I use the prime factorization of the number numbers to find the LCM and GCF.
• Will each method work? Explain why or why not.

Yes, both methods work.

For Maisie's method: It may take students some time to create the lists.

LCM:

42: 42, 84, 126, 168, 210, 252, 294 (note: this is the 6th multiple of 42)

36: 36, 72, 108, 144, 180, 216, 252 (note: this is the 7th multiple of 36)

GCF:

42: 1 × 42, 2 × 21, 3 × 14, 6 ×7

36: 1 × 36, 2 × 18, 3 × 12, 4 × 9, 6 × 6

For Devin's method:

You can write out the prime factorizations of both numbers and see which factors they have in common to find the GCF and include one "copy" of each number's prime factor to find the LCM.

Example:

42 = 2 × 3 × 7

36 = 22 × 32 = 2 × 2 × 3 ×3
